content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easy challenge although I did get stuck printing x/y instead of row/column.

In the Test 7 you collect the same money pile twice (86G at 0 3). I initially read the statement "you pick up all the money" as "you get the money, it disappears from the map". Looks like it isn't so.

Otherwise, very cool puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a very fun puzzle, I very like it ! I hope that a third person will accept this contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear statement, good testcases and fun puzzle.

Also, the convention of most CodinGame puzzles seems to be more of simple space-delimited input values, allowing the player to focus on how to use the data rather than how to parse it.
For example, sending a simpler "0 1 enemy slime" and "2 5 money 10" as the sample enemy/money inputs.

Part of the instructions read "you may pay the goblin 50G".  This sounds optional, which makes the end results non-deterministic.  If the goblin always gets paid, this should read "you pay the goblin 50G"
Interesting puzzle, the statement was clear to follow which helped me solve this quickly. I'll approve this once it's ready

I have taken the liberty to edit the statement directly without writing the comments on the changes I would like to see. (Actually I have written a dozen but feel that they're too long already... :P ) I hope you don't mind!

Although I haven't tried to solve the puzzle, it looks pretty interesting! Keep up the good work.

One thing I haven't changed though: I don't think the tags of DFS and BFS are relevant. Please use some other tags instead. Thanks.

Thank you.
I removed the tags of DFS and BFS.
And I would like to see what part of the description you edited, but I don't have time right now, so I would like to find the edited part again tomorrow or the day after tomorrow. Thank you as always. (*'ω'*)

Thank you.
I set up the ready mode in this program problem. Thanks.

Thank you.
I fixed the description.

Thank you.
I fixed the description, the test caseses, the validators.
It was good because it made it easier to receive input and to focus more on the movement in the map of the program problem. Thanks.

Thank you.
I forgot about the setting that if the player pick up the money on the map it will be disappeared.
Thanks for letting me know.
So I fixed the description and code.
And I fixed the Test case 7 and the Test case 8 answers. Thanks.

Some tips:
• If the statement is long, split them into parts with empty links in between. That'll make it easier to read than having line after line without any breaks.
• Group related points.
• Include bullet points where appropriate.
• Present like you're telling a story (e.g. You have planned a path) instead of merely describing a puzzle (e.g. You are given a string s).
• Variable names are for Input/Output/Constraints sections. They should be avoided in Goal section when appropriate. (In other cases, mentioning variable names in Goal section is better, though. Judge case by case.)

Thank you.
I learned a lot reading the description you rewrote.
Comparing it to my writing description, I felt it was much clearer and easier to read.
I would like to incorporate bullet points and writing like a story into my writing and write more clear the description from now on, referring to the tips you gave me from now on. Thanks.
